repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Deepening Medium Term Budget
            Framework (MTBF) and Strengthening Financial Accountability Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Deepening MTBF and Strengthening
            Financial Accountability Project for Bangladesh received a
            highly unsatisfactory rating with moderate risk to
            development outcome. Both the Bank and the Borrower received
            highly unsatisfactory ratings for their respective
            performances. There were four Level 2 restructurings of the
            project. These restructurings involved changes in project
            design, the revision of the results framework, an increase
            in the funding allocation from, and a closing date extension
            by two months, which applied only to one specific project
            activity to allow students in an ongoing Masters program to
            finish their program. There were several lessons learned
            from this project and include the following: (1) project
            goals could have been less ambitious, more prioritized and
            sequenced, and better informed by previous projects and
            known capacity constraints, (2) more effective consultation
            with government about their priorities and more active
            questioning of paper commitments would also likely have led
            to a less ambitious project, (3) the consequences of the
            lack of a results framework, and results chain analysis was
            evident in the design and implementation. In the absence of
            a more logical explanation of why the public financial
            management (PFM) reforms were being prioritized the links
            between activities to the objectives were ill defined, (4)
            greater use could have been made of the available resources
            to supplement the technical knowledge of the task team,
            especially to provide more intensive oversight of critical
            activities, (5) more up front work to clarify the (PFM) IT
            strategy, system architecture and user requirements, is
            advised before committing large amounts of funding to a
            financial management information system (FMIS) Project, and
            (6) allowing the normal rules preventing officials being
            hired as consultants to be circumvented carries significant risks.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Deepening Medium Term Budget
            Framework (MTBF) and Strengthening Financial Accountability
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Deepening Medium Term Budget Framework (MTBF) and
            Strengthening Financial Accountability Project for
            Bangladesh is to deepen and institutionalize the MTBF and
            build a more strategic and performance oriented budget
            management process, while strengthening financial
            accountability across the expenditure management cycle. This
            restructuring will bring the following changes: (i) partial
            extension of the closing date by two months, from July 31,
            2014 to September 30, 2014 in order to provide the
            additional time needed for 26 scholarship students already
            enrolled in overseas master's programs to complete
            studies and fund costs related to scholarships for August
            and September 2014 from the project grant. Only expenditures
            related to the completion of overseas master's programs
            for the 26 scholarship students already enrolled will be
            eligible after July 31, 2014; (ii) a reallocation between
            spending categories to create a new spending category
            exclusively for expenditures eligible in the extension
            period; and (iii) an amendment to the grant agreement (GA)
            to formalize the above changes.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Deepening Medium Term Budget
            Framework (MTBF) and Strengthening Financial Accountability
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Deepening Medium Term Budget Framework (MTBF) and
            Strengthening Financial Accountability Project for
            Bangladesh is to deepen and institutionalize the MTBF and
            build a more strategic and performance oriented budget
            management process, while strengthening financial
            accountability across the expenditure management cycle. This
            restructuring paper discusses two changes to the project: 1)
            a revision of the results framework for the project to
            adequately capture the achievement of project development
            objectives, intermediate results; and 2) an amendment of the
            grant agreement to enable the project to extend the terms of
            the position as communications specialist from 24 months to
            45 months and to remove from the grant agreement specific
            terms of contracts for specialist positions under the
            Project Management Coordination Unit (PMCU). During the 2012
            restructuring, a revision of the result framework was
            initiated to simplify the original framework, which
            contained more than sixty indicators, and reflect the change
            in component structure. The results framework is to be
            revised for the project to adequately capture the
            achievement of project development objectives, intermediate results.
